   - A-line placed
   - Transfused 1U PRBC for hematocrit < 30 with lasix 40 mg IV

   Assessment and Plan
   47 year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, [**Hospital 827**] transferred from OSH with
   respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome.
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with bronchspasm/obstruction as
   primary pathology at this time with probable infection and acute
   coronary syndrome/congestive heart failure contributing.  He has a
   long-standing history of tobacco abuse and likely COPD but no PFTs in
   our record.  His chest x-ray is unrevealing, however, he had fevers
   prior to presentation and bacterial pathogens, viral/influenza, PCP,
   [**Name10 (NameIs) **] [**Doctor First Name **] remain on the differential; he will need a CT chest for further
   evaluation when stable.  Of note, he was admitted to the MICU one year
   ago for pneumonia with Bordetella bronchisepticum.  He is maintained on
   Bactrim once a day for PCP prophylaxis and azithromycin once a week for
   [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis as an outpatient.  He has acute systolic congestive
   heart failure and apparent decrease in EF from 30% to 15% on OSH TTE.
   - Continue Solu-Medrol 125 mg IV Q8H and Combivent Q4H for COPD
   - Will continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn, and
   azithromycin (changing levofloxacin to azithromycin as patient was on
   levofloacin as an outpatient)
   - Mini-BAL for: Bronchial culture & gram stain; Legionella culture;
   Rapid Respiratory Viral Screen & Culture; Pneumocystis smear; CMV
   culture; Acid fast (TB) culture & smear; Fungal culture
   - Goal I/O even to -500 cc
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain
   medication) for agitation on ventilator to decrease requirements of
   fentanyl/versed
   # Acute coronary syndrome: His coronary history in the setting of ECG
   changes and a positive troponin are concerning for ACS.  Q waves on EKG
   indicate STEMI.  The value of his cardiac enzymes are unlikely to
   represent demand ischemia in the setting of acute illness.
   - Cardiology following; appreciate
   - Continue home aspirin, plavix
   - Continue heparin gtt, integrillin gtt for now until further
   evaluation by cardiology
   - Statin discontinued as outpatient due to interaction with HAART
   regimen
   - Restart beta-blockade to reduce myocardial oxygen requirements once
   blood pressure allows
   - Trend cardiac enzymes and serial ECGs
   - Transfuse hematocrit < 30
   - TTE in the morning
   # Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: Per
   cardiology, his OSH TTE shows EF 15% from previous 30%.  He was given
   lasix at the OSH without mention of fluid balance.
   - Cardiology consult; appreciate
   - Goal I/O even for now; consider diuresis if blood pressure stable
   - Restart beta-blockade once blood pressure allows
   - Start ACEI once blood pressure allows
   # Fevers: Fever to 102 prior to presentation
 apparently afebrile at
   OSH.  Due to infection versus acute coronary syndrome.  If infection,
   most likely etiology would be pulmonary.
   - Continue vancomycin/zosyn/azithromycin for now pending cultures
   - Mini-BAL for above
   - Urinalysis, culture
   - Blood cultures
   - Stool cultures if diarrhea
   - Consider CT chest if stable
   # Acute on chronic anemia: Baseline mid-30s
 hematocrit drop from 30
   to 26 overnight without obvious source of bleeding.  Patient on heparin
   gtt and integrillin gtt.  Chronic anemia likely related to his advanced
   HIV (marrow suppression and/or medication effect).
   - Transfused 1U PRBC overnight
   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfuse hematocrit < 30 given acute coronary syndrome
   - Consider CT abdomen to rule out RP bleed if no appropriate bump after
   transfusion
   - Monitor
   # Hypotension: Resolved.  Patient was on levophed on transfer but now
   off.
   - Monitor
   # Elevated AST: Etiology unclear; may be medication effect versus due
   to infection.  Other liver enzymes within normal limits.
   - Monitor
   # HIV/AIDS: CD4 count 28 with viral load 65.  Known to have virus with
   NNRTI resistance.
   - Continue home HAART regimen
   - Continue fluconazole for fungal prophylaxis
   - Continue Bactrim and [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis
   - OMR indicates that he received the Pneumovax in [**2117**]
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Improved.  Baseline creatinine 1.2,
   recently 1.5 in [**Month (only) 1033**].  [**Month (only) 60**] be due to poor forward flow.
   - Urine electrolytes
   - Renally dose medications
   - Monitor
   # Peripheral neuropathy/recent T8 compression fracture: Neuropathy
   presumed due to stavudine toxicity, per old notes on the OMR; on a very
   large home narcotic requirement.  Compression fracture noted on
   outpatient chest x-ray.
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain
   medication) to decrease requirements of fentanyl/versed
   - Needs CT to further evaluate compression fracture and consider
   neurosurgical evaluation
   # Hyperlipidemia: Hold fibrate for now, but can resume once more
   stable.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Nutrition consult for tube feeds
   Glycemic Control: RISS
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2123-12-28**] 04:30 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2123-12-28**] 08:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Heparin gtt
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, oral care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, and a history of tobacco abuse and likely COPD. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome, and acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated with a tidal volume of 778 mL and a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute. He has a SpO2 of 98% and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 224. His chest x-ray is unrevealing, and he has a history of bronchospasm/obstruction, probable infection, and acute coronary syndrome/congestive heart failure.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has acute coronary syndrome with a positive troponin and ECG changes consistent with STEMI. His cardiac enzymes are unlikely to represent demand ischemia in the setting of acute illness.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's blood pressure is 95/61 mmHg, and his central venous pressure is 5 mmHg.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is 1.5 mg/dL, and he has a history of chronic renal failure.
* Neurological: The patient is agitated and moving all extremities.
* Infectious: The patient has a fever of 102°F prior to presentation and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, or respiratory failure due to COPD exacerbation.
* Cardiac complications: Myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, or arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: Acute kidney injury or worsening of chronic kidney disease.
* Infections: Bacterial, viral, or fungal infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, or central line-associated bloodstream infection.
* Neurological complications: Seizures, cerebral edema, or increased intracranial pressure.
* Gastrointestinal complications: Diarrhea, constipation, or gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 778 mL and a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute.
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected infection.
* Cardiac medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, and beta-blockers.
* Renal medications, including diuretics and renally dosed medications.
* Pain management with methadone and fentanyl.
* Nutrition consult for tube feeds.
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU.

   Assessment and Plan
   47 year-old man with advanced HIV/AIDS presenting transferred from OSH
   with respiratory failure.
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with bronchspasm/obstruction as
   primary pathology at this time with infection and acute coronary
   syndrome/congestive heart failure contributing.  He has a long-standing
   history of tobacco abuse and likely COPD but no PFTs in our record.
   His chest x-ray is unrevealing, however, he had fevers prior to
   presentation and bacterial pathogens, viral/influenza, PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] [**Doctor First Name **]
   remain on the differential; he will need a CT chest for further
   evaluation when stable.  Of note, he was admitted to the MICU one year
   ago for pneumonia with Bordetella bronchisepticum.  He is maintained on
   Bactrim once a day for PCP prophylaxis and azithromycin once a week for
   [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis as an outpatient.  He has acute systolic congestive
   heart failure and apparent decrease in EF from 30% to 15% on OSH TTE.
   - Start Solu-Medrol 125 mg IV Q8H and start Combivent Q4H for COPD
   - Will continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn, and
   azithromycin (changing levofloxacin to azithromycin as patient was on
   levofloacin as an outpatient)
   - Mini-BAL for: Bronchial culture & gram stain; Legionella culture;
   Rapid Respiratory Viral Screen & Culture; Pneumocystis smear; CMV
   culture; Acid fast (TB) culture & smear; Fungal culture
   - Goal I/O even for now; consider diuresis in blood pressure stable
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain
   medication) for agitation on ventilator to decrease requirements of
   fentanyl/versed
   # NSTEMI: His coronary history in the setting of ECG changes and a
   positive troponin are concerning for ACS.  The value of his cardiac
   enzymes are unlikely to represent demand ischemia in the setting of
   acute illness.
   - Cardiology consult; appreciate
   - Continue home aspirin, plavix
   - Continue heparin gtt, integrillin gtt started at OSH
   - Statin discontinued as outpatient due to interaction with HAART
   regimen
   - Restart beta-blockade to reduce myocardial oxygen requirements once
   blood pressure allows
   - Trend cardiac enzymes and serial ECGs
   - Transfuse hematocrit < 30
   - TTE in the morning
   # Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: Per
   cardiology, his OSH TTE shows EF 15% from previous 30%.  He was given
   lasix at the OSH without mention of fluid balance.
   - Cardiology consult; appreciate
   - Goal I/O even for now; consider diuresis if blood pressure stable
   - Restart beta-blockade to reduce myocardial oxygen requirements once
   blood pressure allows
   # Fevers: Fever to 102 prior to presentation
 apparently afebrile at
   OSH.  Most likely due to acute pulmonary process.
   - Mini-BAL for above
   - Urinalysis, culture
   - Blood cultures
   - Stool cultures if diarrhea
   # Hypotension: Resolved.  Patient was on levophed on transfer but now
   off.
   - Monitor
   # Acute on chronic anemia: Chronic anemia likely related to his
   advanced HIV (marrow suppression and/or medication effect).  Baseline
   mid-30s.
   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfuse hematocrit < 30 given acute coronary syndrome
   - Monitor
   # Elevated AST: Etiology unclear; may be medication effect versus due
   to infection.  Other liver enzymes within normal limits.
   - Monitor
   # HIV/AIDS: CD4 count 28 with viral load 65.  Known to have virus with
   NNRTI resistance.
   - Continue home HAART regimen
   - Continue fluconazole for fungal prophylaxis
   - Continue Bactrim and [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis
   - OMR indicates that he received the Pneumovax in [**2117**]
   # Chronic renal failure: Baseline creatinine 1.2, recently 1.5 in
   [**Month (only) 1033**].  [**Month (only) 60**] be due to poor forward flow.
   - Urine electrolytes
   - Renally dose medications
   - Monitor
   # Peripheral neuropathy/recent T8 compression fracture: Neuropathy
   presumed due to stavudine toxicity, per old notes on the OMR; on a very
   large home narcotic requirement.  Compression fracture noted on
   outpatient chest x-ray.
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain
   medication) to decrease requirements of fentanyl/versed
   - Consider neurosurgical evaluation for compression fracture
   # Hyperlipidemia: Hold fibrate for now, but can resume once more
   stable.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control: RISS
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2123-12-28**] 04:30 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2123-12-28**] 08:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Heparin SC
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, oral care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and the development of bronchospasm/obstruction, probable infection, and acute coronary syndrome/congestive heart failure can worsen his condition.
2. Acute coronary syndrome: The patient's cardiac enzymes are trending down, but he still requires close monitoring, and the possibility of STEMI or non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) cannot be ruled out.
3. Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: The patient's ejection fraction (EF) has decreased from 30% to 15%, and he requires close monitoring and management of his fluid balance.
4. Fevers: The patient's fever may be due to infection, and the possibility of pulmonary infection is high. He requires further evaluation with mini-BAL and cultures.
5. Acute on chronic anemia: The patient's hematocrit has dropped from 30 to 26 overnight, and he requires close monitoring and transfusion support.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has resolved, but he requires continued monitoring to prevent recurrence.
7. Elevated AST: The etiology of the patient's elevated AST is unclear, and he requires close monitoring to rule out medication effect or infection.
8. HIV/AIDS: The patient's CD4 count is 28, and his viral load is 65. He requires continued HAART regimen and prophylaxis for opportunistic infections.
9. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine has improved, but he requires continued monitoring and adjustment of his medications to prevent further deterioration.
10. Peripheral neuropathy/recent T8 compression fracture: The patient's peripheral neuropathy is presumed due to stavudine toxicity, and he requires continued pain management and evaluation for compression fracture.

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

1. Nutrition: Tube feeds
2. Glycemic control: RISS
3. Lines: Multi-lumen and 20-gauge lines
4. Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
5. Monitoring: Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory, cardiac, and renal status
6. Medications: Continued administration of antibiotics, antivirals, and antifungals
7. Imaging studies: CT chest and abdomen to evaluate for pulmonary and abdominal pathology
8. Procedures: Mini-BAL and cardiac enzymes

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU.

   syndrome/congestive heart failure contributing.  He has a long-standing

   presentation and bacterial pathogens, viral/influenza, PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] [**Doctor First Name **]
   remain on the differential; he will need a CT chest for further
   evaluation when stable.  Of note, he was admitted to the MICU one year
   ago for pneumonia with Bordetella bronchisepticum.  He is maintained on
   Bactrim once a day for PCP prophylaxis and azithromycin once a week for
   [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis as an outpatient.  He has acute systolic congestive
   heart failure and apparent decrease in EF from 30% to 15% on OSH TTE.
   - Start Solu-Medrol 125 mg IV Q8H and start Combivent Q4H for COPD
   - Will continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn, and

   levofloacin as an outpatient)

   culture; Acid fast (TB) culture & smear; Fungal culture
   - Goal I/O even for now; consider diuresis in blood pressure stable
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain
   medication) for agitation on ventilator to decrease requirements of
   fentanyl/versed
   # NSTEMI: His coronary history in the setting of ECG changes and a
   positive troponin are concerning for ACS.  The value of his cardiac
   enzymes are unlikely to represent demand ischemia in the setting of
   acute illness.
   - Cardiology consult; appreciate
   - Continue home aspirin, plavix
   - Continue heparin gtt, integrillin gtt started at OSH
   - Statin discontinued as outpatient due to interaction with HAART
   regimen
   - Restart beta-blockade to reduce myocardial oxygen requirements once

   - Trend cardiac enzymes and serial ECGs
   - Transfuse hematocrit < 30

   cardiology, his OSH TTE shows EF 15% from previous 30%.  He was given
   lasix at the OSH without mention of fluid balance.
   - Cardiology consult; appreciate
   - Goal I/O even for now; consider diuresis if blood pressure stable
   - Restart beta-blockade to reduce myocardial oxygen requirements once
   blood pressure allows
   # Fevers: Fever to 102 prior to presentation
 apparently afebrile at

   - Mini-BAL for above
   - Urinalysis, culture

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old man with advanced HIV/AIDS who presented to the ICU with respiratory failure. The patient has a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), acute coronary syndrome (ACS), congestive heart failure, and chronic renal failure.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The chest x-ray is unrevealing, and a CT chest is planned when the patient is stable.
* Acute coronary syndrome: The patient has elevated cardiac enzymes and ECG changes, which are concerning for ACS.
* Congestive heart failure: The patient has acute systolic congestive heart failure and a decreased ejection fraction (EF) of 15%.
* Chronic renal failure: The patient has a baseline creatinine of 1.2, which has recently increased to 1.5.
* Anemia: The patient has a chronic anemia likely related to his advanced HIV and is being transfused with packed red blood cells.
* Liver enzymes: The patient has elevated AST levels, which may be due to medication effect or infection.
* HIV/AIDS: The patient has a CD4 count of 28 and a viral load of 65, with resistance to non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs).

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia: The patient has a high risk of developing pneumonia due to his chronic respiratory disease and immunocompromised state.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's ACS and congestive heart failure put him at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac arrest.
* Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal failure and acute kidney injury increase his risk of developing end-stage renal disease.
* Hepatic failure: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and chronic liver disease put him at risk for hepatic failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's immunocompromised state and chronic infections increase his risk of developing sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory disease and acute respiratory failure put him at risk for respiratory failure.
* Neurological complications: The patient's peripheral neuropathy and recent T8 compression fracture put him at risk for neurological complications such as paralysis and loss of motor function.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Broad-spectrum antibiotics for pneumonia and sepsis
* Anti-coagulation therapy for ACS and pulmonary embolism
* Diuretics for congestive heart failure and fluid overload
* Pain management with methadone and fentanyl
* Cardiology consult for ACS and congestive heart failure
* Infectious disease consult for pneumonia and sepsis
* Pulmonology consult for respiratory failure
* Neurosurgical evaluation for compression fracture

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, and respiratory failure, who was transferred from OSH with acute coronary syndrome. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. His current medications include Solu-Medrol, combivent, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. His cardiac enzymes are trending down, and he has been started on low-dose metoprolol and ACEI.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 50%. His ABG results show a pH of 7.41, a PaCO2 of 54, and a PaO2 of 188. His respiratory support includes a CPAP/PSV ventilator mode, with a Vt of 1,291 mL and a PS of 10 cmH2O.

The patient's cardiovascular status is stable, with a blood pressure of 99/64 mmHg and a heart rate of 86 bpm. His cardiac enzymes are trending down, and he has been started on low-dose metoprolol and ACEI.

The patient's neurological status is stable, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15. He is agitated and moving all extremities.

The patient's laboratory results show a hematocrit of 25.9%, a platelet count of 133 K/uL, and a white blood cell count of 4.2 K/uL. His blood cultures are pending.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he may be at risk for further deterioration due to his underlying respiratory disease and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac enzymes are trending down, but he may be at risk for further cardiac complications due to his underlying CAD and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
3. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised status and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation may increase his risk for infection.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's agitation and movement may be indicative of neurological complications, such as seizures or increased intracranial pressure.
5. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's recent transfusion and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation may increase his risk for hemorrhagic complications.
6. Renal failure: The patient's baseline creatinine level is 1.2, and his recent creatinine level is 1.5. He may be at risk for further renal failure due to his underlying renal disease and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
7. Liver failure: The patient's elevated AST level may be indicative of liver failure, which could be exacerbated by his underlying liver disease and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
8. HIV-related complications: The patient's advanced HIV disease may increase his risk for HIV-related complications, such as opportunistic infections or HIV-related neurocognitive disorders.

Overall, the patient's medical condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, and respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome. He was transferred from the operating room to the ICU with severe COPD, bilateral consolidations on imaging, and a moderate to severe decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 20-25%. He was treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, and a mini-BAL was performed to rule out infection. His cardiac enzymes are trending down, and he was started on low-dose metoprolol and ACEI. He has a history of HIV/AIDS, chronic anemia, and peripheral neuropathy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk of developing further respiratory failure due to his severe COPD and bilateral consolidations.
2. Acute coronary syndrome: The patient's cardiac enzymes are trending down, but he is at risk of developing further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
3. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised status and history of HIV/AIDS make him susceptible to opportunistic infections, such as Pneumocystis pneumonia or Legionnaires' disease.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fever and bilateral consolidations on imaging suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
5. Bleeding: The patient's history of chronic anemia and recent transfusion of 3 units of PRBCs make him at risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of heparin and integrillin therapy.
6. Renal failure: The patient's baseline creatinine is 1.2, and he has a history of chronic renal failure, which could worsen with further insult, such as sepsis or nephrotoxic medications.
7. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated AST levels could indicate liver dysfunction, which could be due to medication toxicity, infection, or underlying liver disease.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's history of peripheral neuropathy and recent compression fracture make him at risk of developing further neurological complications, such as spinal cord compression or peripheral nerve damage.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and provide supportive care, such as oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation, as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac status with medications, such as metoprolol and ACEI, and consider further interventions, such as cardiac catheterization or coronary artery bypass grafting, if necessary.
3. Continue to treat the patient's infection with broad-spectrum antibiotics and consider further diagnostic tests, such as bronchoscopy or CT scan, to rule out other potential infections.
4. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust his medications and fluids as necessary to prevent further renal dysfunction.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function closely and adjust his medications and therapy as necessary to prevent further liver dysfunction.
7. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider further evaluation and management, such as CT scan or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), if necessary.

   Bactrim once a day for PCP prophylaxis and azithromycin once a week for
   [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis as an outpatient.  He has acute systolic congestive

   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with bronchspasm/obstruction as
   primary pathology at this time with probable infection and acute

   [**Name10 (NameIs) **] [**Doctor First Name **] remain on the differential; he will need a CT chest for further
   evaluation when stable.  Of note, he was admitted to the MICU one year

   Bactrim once a day for PCP prophylaxis and azithromycin once a week for
   [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis as an outpatient.  He has acute systolic congestive
   heart failure and apparent decrease in EF from 30% to 15% on OSH TTE.
   - Continue Solu-Medrol 125 mg IV Q8H and Combivent Q4H for COPD
   - Will continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn, and

   - Mini-BAL for: Bronchial culture & gram stain; Legionella culture;

   - Goal I/O even to -500 cc
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain
   medication) for agitation on ventilator to decrease requirements of
   fentanyl/versed
   # Acute coronary syndrome: His coronary history in the setting of ECG
   changes and a positive troponin are concerning for ACS.  Q waves on EKG
   indicate STEMI.  The value of his cardiac enzymes are unlikely to
   represent demand ischemia in the setting of acute illness.  Cardiac
   enzymes starting to trend down.
   - Cardiology following; appreciate
   - Continue home aspirin, plavix
   - Continue heparin gtt, integrillin gtt for now until further
   evaluation by cardiology
   - Statin discontinued as outpatient due to interaction with HAART
   regimen
   - Restart beta-blockade to reduce myocardial oxygen requirements once
   blood pressure allows
   - Trend cardiac enzymes and serial ECGs
   - Transfuse hematocrit < 30
   - TTE in the morning
   # Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: Per
   cardiology, his OSH TTE shows EF 15% from previous 30%.  He was given

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, and a history of tobacco abuse, likely COPD. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome, and acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and a PEEP of 10 cmH2O. His SpO2 is 98%. His respiratory rate is 6 breaths per minute, and his tidal volume is 1,291 mL.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has acute coronary syndrome with a positive troponin and Q waves on ECG, indicating STEMI. His cardiac enzymes are trending down.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is 99/64 mmHg, and his central venous pressure is 15 mmHg.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine has improved from 1.2 to 1.5 mg/dL.
* Neurological status: The patient's neurological status is not well-documented in the note.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has had a drop in hematocrit from 30 to 26 overnight without an obvious source of bleeding. He has received 2 units of PRBCs.
* Infectious status: The patient has a fever of 102°F, and his blood cultures are pending. He is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require further respiratory support.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's acute coronary syndrome and cardiac enzymes may indicate ongoing myocardial damage.
* Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure and central venous pressure may indicate ongoing cardiovascular instability.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he may require further monitoring and management of his renal function.
* Infection: The patient's fever and blood cultures may indicate ongoing infection, which requires prompt treatment and management.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's drop in hematocrit and guaiac-positive stools may indicate ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding, which requires prompt evaluation and management.
* Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is not well-documented in the note, and he may require further evaluation and management of any neurological complications.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and a PEEP of 10 cmH2O
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected infection
* Fentanyl and midazolam for sedation
* Lasix for diuresis
* Heparin and integrillin for anticoagulation
* Methadone for pain management
* Cardiovascular medications, including aspirin, plavix, and statin
* Renal medications, including diuretics and renally dosed medications

The patient's discharge plan includes:

* Transfer to the cardiology service for further evaluation and management of his acute coronary syndrome
* Further evaluation and management of his respiratory failure
* Monitoring of his hemodynamic status and cardiovascular function
* Monitoring of his renal function and potential need for further dialysis
* Further evaluation and management of his gastrointestinal status and potential need for further transfusions
* Further evaluation and management of his neurological status and potential need for further imaging studies.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, and a history of tobacco abuse and likely COPD. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome, and acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: He has multifactorial respiratory failure with bronchospasm/obstruction as the primary pathology, with probable infection and acute coronary syndrome/congestive heart failure contributing.
* Acute coronary syndrome: His coronary history in the setting of ECG changes and a positive troponin are concerning for ACS. Q waves on EKG indicate STEMI. Cardiac enzymes are starting to trend down.
* Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: His OSH TTE shows EF 15% from previous 30%. He was given lasix at the OSH without mention of fluid balance.
* Fevers: Fever to 102 prior to presentation, apparently afebrile at OSH. Due to infection versus acute coronary syndrome. If infection, most likely etiology would be pulmonary.
* Acute on chronic anemia: Baseline mid-30s hematocrit drop from 30 to 26 overnight without obvious source of bleeding. Patient on heparin gtt and integrillin gtt.
* Hypotension: Resolved. Patient was on levophed on transfer but now off.
* Elevated AST: Etiology unclear; may be medication effect versus due to infection. Other liver enzymes within normal limits.
* HIV/AIDS: CD4 count 28 with viral load 65. Known to have virus with NNRTI resistance.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: Improved. Baseline creatinine 1.2, recently 1.5 in [**Month (only) 1033**]. [**Month (only) 60**] be due to poor forward flow.
* Peripheral neuropathy/recent T8 compression fracture: Neuropathy presumed due to stavudine toxicity, per old notes on the OMR; on a very large home narcotic requirement. Compression fracture noted on outpatient chest x-ray.
* Hyperlipidemia: Hold fibrate for now, but can resume once more stable.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: Continued bronchospasm/obstruction, infection, and acute coronary syndrome/congestive heart failure can exacerbate respiratory failure.
* Acute coronary syndrome: Continued cardiac enzymes trending down, but potential for further cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
* Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: Continued cardiac dysfunction can lead to further decompensation and potential for cardiac arrest.
* Fevers: Continued fever can indicate ongoing infection, which can lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
* Acute on chronic anemia: Continued bleeding or further anemia can lead to hypovolemic shock.
* Hypotension: Potential for further hypotension or cardiac arrest.
* Elevated AST: Continued liver dysfunction can lead to further liver damage and potential for liver failure.
* HIV/AIDS: Continued HIV replication can lead to further immunosuppression and potential for opportunistic infections.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: Continued kidney dysfunction can lead to further renal failure and potential for dialysis.
* Peripheral neuropathy/recent T8 compression fracture: Continued compression on the spinal cord can lead to further spinal cord damage and potential for paralysis.
* Hyperlipidemia: Continued high lipids can lead to further cardiovascular complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue Solu-Medrol 125 mg IV Q8H and Combivent Q4H for COPD
* Continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn, and azithromycin
* Mini-BAL for bronchial culture & gram stain; Legionella culture; Rapid Respiratory Viral Screen & Culture; Pneumocystis smear; CMV culture; Acid fast (TB) culture & smear; Fungal culture
* Goal I/O even to -500 cc
* Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H for agitation on ventilator to decrease requirements of fentanyl/versed
* Chest CT does not show significant consolidation except for small area in LLL
* Cardiology following; appreciate
* Continue home aspirin, plavix
* Continue heparin gtt, integrillin gtt for now until further evaluation by cardiology
* Statin discontinued as outpatient due to interaction with HAART regimen
* Restart beta-blockade to reduce myocardial oxygen requirements once blood pressure allows
* Trend cardiac enzymes and serial ECGs
* Transfuse hematocrit < 30
* TTE in the morning
* Continue home HAART regimen
* Continue fluconazole for fungal prophylaxis
* Continue Bactrim and [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis
* OMR indicates that he received the Pneumovax in [**2117**]
* Urine electrolytes
* Renally dose medications
* Monitor
* Restart beta-blockade once blood pressure allows
* Start ACEI once blood pressure allows
* Consider CT chest if stable

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, and a history of tobacco abuse. He was transferred to the ICU from OSH with respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome, and acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with bronchospasm/obstruction as primary pathology, probable infection, and acute coronary syndrome/congestive heart failure contributing.
* Acute coronary syndrome: Q waves on EKG indicate STEMI, and cardiac enzymes are trending down.
* Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: EF 15% from previous 30%.
* Fevers: Fever to 102 prior to presentation, now apparently afebrile.
* Acute on chronic anemia: Hematocrit drop from 30 to 26 overnight without obvious source of bleeding.
* Hypotension: Resolved.
* Elevated AST: Etiology unclear, may be medication effect versus due to infection.
* HIV/AIDS: CD4 count 28 with viral load 65, known to have virus with NNRTI resistance.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: Improved, baseline creatinine 1.2, recently 1.5.
* Peripheral neuropathy/recent T8 compression fracture: Neuropathy presumed due to stavudine toxicity, compression fracture noted on outpatient chest x-ray.
* Hyperlipidemia: Hold fibrate for now, but can resume once more stable.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, sepsis, and respiratory acidosis.
* Acute coronary syndrome: Myocardial infarction, cardiogenic shock, and arrhythmias.
* Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: Cardiac tamponade, cardiogenic shock, and arrhythmias.
* Fevers: Sepsis, pneumonia, and meningitis.
* Acute on chronic anemia: Bleeding, transfusion reactions, and anemia exacerbation.
* Hypotension: Cardiac arrest, shock, and organ failure.
* Elevated AST: Liver failure, hepatitis, and cirrhosis.
* HIV/AIDS: Opportunistic infections, antiretroviral therapy toxicity, and immunodeficiency-related complications.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: Renal failure, electrolyte imbalance, and acidosis.
* Peripheral neuropathy/recent T8 compression fracture: Neurological deficits, pain, and spinal cord compression.
* Hyperlipidemia: Pancreatitis, atherosclerosis, and cardiovascular events.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Respiratory support with CPAP/PSV and O2 delivery device.
* Antibiotics for infection, including vancomycin, zosyn, and azithromycin.
* Cardiovascular medications, including aspirin, plavix, and heparin.
* Diuretics, including lasix, for congestive heart failure.
* Pain management with methadone and fentanyl.
* Antiretroviral therapy for HIV/AIDS.
* Renal dose medications and monitoring for acute on chronic renal failure.
* Neurosurgical evaluation for peripheral neuropathy/recent T8 compression fracture.
* Follow-up with cardiology, infectious disease, and neurosurgery specialists.

   our record.  His chest x-ray is unrevealing, however, he had fevers
   prior to presentation and bacterial pathogens, viral/influenza, PCP,
   [**Name10 (NameIs) **] [**Doctor First Name **] remain on the differential; he will need a CT chest for further
   evaluation when stable.  Of note, he was admitted to the MICU one year
   ago for pneumonia with Bordetella bronchisepticum.  He is maintained on
   Bactrim once a day for PCP prophylaxis and azithromycin once a week for
   [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis as an outpatient.  He has acute systolic congestive
   heart failure and apparent decrease in EF from 30% to 15% on OSH TTE.
   - Continue Solu-Medrol 125 mg IV Q8H and Combivent Q4H for COPD
   - Will continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn, and
   azithromycin
   - Mini-BAL for: Bronchial culture & gram stain; Legionella culture;
   Rapid Respiratory Viral Screen & Culture; Pneumocystis smear; CMV
   culture; Acid fast (TB) culture & smear; Fungal culture
   - Goal I/O even to -500 cc
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain
   medication) for agitation on ventilator to decrease requirements of
   fentanyl/versed
   - Chest CT does not show significant consolidation except for small
   area in LLL
   # Acute coronary syndrome: His coronary history in the setting of ECG
   changes and a positive troponin are concerning for ACS.  Q waves on EKG
   indicate STEMI.  The value of his cardiac enzymes are unlikely to
   represent demand ischemia in the setting of acute illness.  Cardiac
   enzymes starting to trend down.
   - Cardiology following; appreciate
   - Continue home aspirin, plavix
   - Continue heparin gtt, integrillin gtt for now until further
   evaluation by cardiology
   - Statin discontinued as outpatient due to interaction with HAART
   regimen
   - Restart beta-blockade to reduce myocardial oxygen requirements once
   blood pressure allows
   - Trend cardiac enzymes and serial ECGs
   - Transfuse hematocrit < 30
   - TTE in the morning
   # Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: Per
   cardiology, his OSH TTE shows EF 15% from previous 30%.  He was given
   lasix at the OSH without mention of fluid balance.
   - Cardiology consult; appreciate
   - Goal I/O even for now; consider diuresis if blood pressure stable
   - Restart beta-blockade once blood pressure allows
   - Start ACEI once blood pressure allows
   # Fevers: Fever to 102 prior to presentation
 apparently afebrile at
   OSH.  Due to infection versus acute coronary syndrome.  If infection,
   most likely etiology would be pulmonary.
   - Continue vancomycin/zosyn/azithromycin for now pending cultures
   plan to discontinue at 48 hours if cultures negative
   - Mini-BAL for above
   - Urinalysis, culture
   - Blood cultures
   - Stool cultures if diarrhea
   - Consider CT chest if stable
   # Acute on chronic anemia: Baseline mid-30s
 hematocrit drop from 30
   to 26 overnight without obvious source of bleeding.  Patient on heparin
   gtt and integrillin gtt.  Chronic anemia likely related to his advanced
   HIV (marrow suppression and/or medication effect).
   - Transfused 1U PRBC overnight
   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfuse hematocrit < 30 given acute coronary syndrome
   - Consider CT abdomen to rule out RP bleed if no appropriate bump after
   transfusion
   - Monitor
   # Hypotension: Resolved.  Patient was on levophed on transfer but now
   off.
   - Monitor
   # Elevated AST: Etiology unclear; may be medication effect versus due
   to infection.  Other liver enzymes within normal limits.
   - Monitor
   # HIV/AIDS: CD4 count 28 with viral load 65.  Known to have virus with
   NNRTI resistance.
   - Continue home HAART regimen
   - Continue fluconazole for fungal prophylaxis
   - Continue Bactrim and [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis
   - OMR indicates that he received the Pneumovax in [**2117**]
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Improved.  Baseline creatinine 1.2,
   recently 1.5 in [**Month (only) 1033**].  [**Month (only) 60**] be due to poor forward flow.
   - Urine electrolytes
   - Renally dose medications
   - Monitor
   # Peripheral neuropathy/recent T8 compression fracture: Neuropathy
   presumed due to stavudine toxicity, per old notes on the OMR; on a very
   large home narcotic requirement.  Compression fracture noted on
   outpatient chest x-ray.
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain
   medication) to decrease requirements of fentanyl/versed
   - Needs CT to further evaluate compression fracture and consider
   neurosurgical evaluation
   # Hyperlipidemia: Hold fibrate for now, but can resume once more
   stable.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2123-12-28**] 04:30 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2123-12-28**] 08:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2123-12-29**] 08:41 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, and a history of tobacco abuse. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome, and acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 86 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 99/64 mmHg. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 1,291 mL and a respiratory rate of 6 breaths per minute.

The patient has a history of chronic anemia, which has worsened overnight, and is being treated with blood transfusions. He also has a history of HIV/AIDS, with a CD4 count of 28 and a viral load of 65.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating acute coronary syndrome. His cardiac enzymes are trending down, and he is being treated with heparin and aspirin. He also has elevated liver enzymes, which may be due to medication effects or infection.

The patient's radiology results show a chest CT with no significant consolidation except for a small area in the left lower lobe. He also has a history of pneumonia with Bordetella bronchisepticum and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient's medications include solu-Medrol, Combivent, vancomycin, zosyn, azithromycin, and methadone. He is also receiving insulin and sliding-scale insulin for glycemic control.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics for infection
* Mini-BAL for bronchial culture and gram stain
* Cardiac enzymes and serial ECGs
* Transfusions for anemia
* Restarting beta-blockade once blood pressure allows
* TTE in the morning
* Monitoring for hypotension and elevated AST

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to bronchospasm, obstruction, or infection
* Acute coronary syndrome with potential for myocardial infarction
* Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure
* Infection, including pneumonia, sepsis, and bacteremia
* Anemia, which may worsen due to ongoing bleeding or medication effects
* Hypotension, which may worsen due to cardiac compromise or bleeding
* Elevated AST, which may be due to medication effects or infection
* HIV/AIDS complications, including opportunistic infections and medication toxicity
* Renal failure, which may worsen due to poor forward flow or medication effects
* Peripheral neuropathy, which may worsen due to medication effects or compression fracture

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old man with HIV and low CD4 count, admitted with respiratory failure and acute coronary syndrome (ACS). He has been treated with antibiotics, antivirals, and antiretroviral therapy. The patient's condition is critical, and he is currently being treated in the intensive care unit (ICU).

The patient's respiratory status has been complicated by acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD), which has led to respiratory failure. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 742 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. His respiratory rate is 11 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98%.

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, as he has had an ACS, which has been treated with thrombolytic therapy. His troponin levels are elevated, and his creatine kinase (CK) and CK-MB levels are also elevated. He is receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin and integrilin, but this has been discontinued.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dL. His white blood cell count is 4.2 K/uL, and his platelet count is 133 K/uL. His liver function tests (LFTs) are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 27 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 73 IU/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for HIV, low CD4 count, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He is receiving antiretroviral therapy and prophylactic antibiotics.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk of developing further respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's ACS has been treated, but he is at risk of developing further cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state makes him susceptible to infection, particularly with opportunistic pathogens.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to worsen if not treated promptly.
5. Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's LFTs are mildly elevated, and he is at risk of developing further hepatic dysfunction.
6. Renal dysfunction: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is at risk of developing further renal dysfunction.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's HIV infection and antiretroviral therapy may increase his risk of neurological complications, such as seizures or encephalopathy.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical condition, requiring close monitoring and management in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with respiratory failure and acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The patient was admitted with febrile respiratory failure and apparent ACS, and has been receiving treatment for pneumonia (PNA) and ACS.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 85 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/74 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with a SpO2 of 98% and a respiratory rate of 11 breaths per minute.

The patient has a history of allergies to amitriptyline, benzodiazepines, and morphine, and has received antibiotics, including vancomycin, azithromycin, and piperacillin. The patient is also receiving infusions of midazolam, fentanyl, and furosemide.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dL, and elevated troponin-T levels, indicating cardiac damage. The patient's liver function tests are also abnormal, with elevated levels of ALT and AST.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation. The patient's neurologic examination is also limited, with the patient not responding to verbal commands.

The patient's plan of care includes continued treatment for PNA and ACS, as well as management of their anemia and cardiac damage. The patient is also receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer.

Potential medical complications that could arise in this patient include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and febrile respiratory failure suggest that they may be at risk for developing pneumonia.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's ACS and elevated troponin-T levels suggest that they may be at risk for developing cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's need for mechanical ventilation and respiratory support suggests that they may be at risk for developing respiratory failure.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if they are unable to receive adequate blood transfusions.
5. DVT: The patient's prophylaxis for DVT may not be effective if they develop a DVT.
6. Stress ulcer: The patient's prophylaxis for stress ulcer may not be effective if they develop a stress ulcer.
7. Infection: The patient's febrile respiratory failure and pneumonia suggest that they may be at risk for developing infections.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve their outcomes.

   47 year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, [**Hospital 827**] transferred from OSH with
   respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome.
   # Respiratory failure: Severe COPD on imaging
 less wheezy on
   examination today.  Question superimposed infection
 CT shows
   bilateral consolidations, likely atelectasis, but will treat for
   infection given immunocompromised status.  Not much evidence of
   congestive heart failure contributing per CT from yesterday.
   - Change Solu-Medrol 125 mg IV Q8H to prednisone 60 mg PO daily
   - Continue combivent Q4H for COPD with albuterol Q1-2H PRN
   - Continue beclomethasone
   - Will continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn x 8
   days
   - Mini-BAL for: Bronchial culture & gram stain; Legionella culture;
   Rapid Respiratory Viral Screen & Culture; Pneumocystis smear; CMV
   culture; Acid fast (TB) culture & smear; Fungal culture
 all NGTD
   - Goal I/O even
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain
   medication) for agitation on ventilator to decrease requirements of
   fentanyl/versed
   # Acute coronary syndrome: Completed infarct
 question mid-LAD
   stenosis.  Cardiac enzymes trending down.
   - Cardiology following; appreciate -> no intervention at this time,
   stress test when improved
   - Continue aspirin, plavix, metoprolol
 add on lisinopril today
   - Statin discontinued as outpatient due to interaction with HAART
   regimen
   # Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: TTE
   yesterday shows EF 20-25% from 30%.
   - Cardiology following; appreciate
   - Goal I/O even for now
   - Continue metoprolol
 add on lisinopril today
   - Cardiology follow-up as an outpatient for question AICD
   # Fevers: Fever to 102 prior to presentation
 afebrile since.  Due to
   infection versus acute coronary syndrome.  If infection, most likely
   etiology would be pulmonary.  CT shows bilateral consolidations, likely
   atelectasis, but will treat for infection given immunocompromised
   status.
   - Will continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn x 8
   days
   - Mini-BAL for: Bronchial culture & gram stain; Legionella culture;
   Rapid Respiratory Viral Screen & Culture; Pneumocystis smear; CMV
   culture; Acid fast (TB) culture & smear; Fungal culture
 all NGTD
   - Urinalysis, culture
 NGTD
   - Blood cultures
 NGTD
   - Stool cultures
 NGTD
   # Acute on chronic anemia: Status post 3U PRBC.  BRBPR in setting of
   heparin gtt and integrillin gtt, none since.  No RP bleed on CT
   yesterday.  Chronic anemia likely related to his advanced HIV (marrow
   suppression and/or medication effect).
   - Guaiac stools
   - Recheck hematocrit in afternoon and transfuse < 28
   - Monitor
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Stable.  Baseline creatinine 1.2,
   recently 1.5 in [**Month (only) 1033**].
   - Goal even today
   - Renally dose medications
   - Monitor
   # Hypotension: Resolved.  Patient was on levophed on transfer but now
   off.
   - Monitor
   # Elevated AST: Etiology unclear; may be medication effect versus due
   to infection.  Other liver enzymes within normal limits.
   - Monitor
   # HIV/AIDS: CD4 count 28 with viral load 65.  Known to have virus with
   NNRTI resistance.
   - Continue home HAART regimen
   - Continue fluconazole for fungal prophylaxis
   - Continue Bactrim and [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis
   - OMR indicates that he received the Pneumovax in [**2117**]
   # Peripheral neuropathy/recent T8 compression fracture: Neuropathy
   presumed due to stavudine toxicity, per old notes on the OMR; on a very
   large home narcotic requirement.  Compression fracture noted on
   outpatient chest x-ray
 chronic on imaging here.
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain

   # Hyperlipidemia: Hold fibrate for now, but can resume once more

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the key points as follows:

* The patient is a 47-year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, and respiratory failure, transferred from the operating room to the ICU with acute coronary syndrome.
* The patient's respiratory status has improved slightly, with decreased work of breathing and autoPEEP, but remains severely compromised.
* The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a PEEP of 14 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%.
* The patient's cardiac enzymes are trending down, and a completed infarct is suspected, with a question of mid-LAD stenosis.
* The patient has a history of chronic anemia, acute on chronic renal failure, and peripheral neuropathy, with a recent T8 compression fracture.
* The patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected infection, and a mini-BAL is planned to obtain bronchial cultures and other specimens.
* The patient's electrolytes and lab results are within normal limits, except for elevated AST, which may be due to medication effect or infection.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still severely compromised, and further deterioration could lead to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac enzymes are trending down, but the completed infarct and suspected mid-LAD stenosis may lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac rupture.
3. Infection: The patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, but the risk of infection remains high, particularly with the patient's immunocompromised status.
4. Renal failure: The patient has a history of acute on chronic renal failure, and further deterioration could lead to worsening renal function and potential need for dialysis.
5. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of peripheral neuropathy and a recent T8 compression fracture, which could lead to further neurological complications, such as paralysis or weakness.
6. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient has a history of bleeding complications, including BRBPR and recent T8 compression fracture, which could lead to further hemorrhagic complications.
7. Metabolic complications: The patient has a history of chronic anemia, and further deterioration could lead to worsening anemia, fatigue, and decreased tolerance to therapy.
8. Medication side effects: The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, antiretroviral therapy, and pain management medications, which could lead to side effects, such as liver toxicity, allergic reactions, or medication interactions.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of their condition and potential medical complications:

**Respiratory Status:**

* The patient is intubated and receiving CPAP/PSV ventilation with a PEEP of 14 cmH2O, FiO2 of 50%, and a respiratory rate of 7 breaths per minute.
* The patient's SpO2 is 95% and their ABG shows a pH of 7.42, PaO2 of 186, and PaCO2 of 59 mmHg.
* The patient has severe COPD with bilateral consolidations and atelectasis on CT imaging, and is being treated for possible superimposed infection.

**Cardiovascular Status:**

* The patient has a completed infarct with a question of mid-LAD stenosis.
* Cardiac enzymes are trending down.
* The patient is being treated with aspirin, Plavix, and metoprolol.

**Renal Status:**

* The patient has stable renal function with a baseline creatinine of 1.2 and a recent value of 1.5.
* The patient is being monitored for potential changes in renal function.

**Hematological Status:**

* The patient has acute-on-chronic anemia with a hematocrit of 29.5%.
* The patient is being monitored for bleeding and is receiving guaiac stools and rechecking hematocrit.

**Neurological Status:**

* The patient has acute-on-chronic peripheral neuropathy and a recent T8 compression fracture.
* The patient is being treated with methadone for pain management.

**Infectious Status:**

* The patient has a fever of 102 prior to presentation, which has resolved.
* The patient is being treated for possible infection with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and zosyn.

**Other Complications:**

* The patient has elevated AST levels, which may be due to medication effect or infection.
* The patient has hyperlipidemia, which is being managed with medication.

**Potential Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate further due to underlying COPD and possible superimposed infection.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac enzymes are trending down, but there is still a question of mid-LAD stenosis, which could lead to further cardiac complications.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal function is stable, but there is a risk of further decline in function due to underlying disease and potential medication toxicity.
* Bleeding: The patient has a risk of bleeding due to underlying anemia and anticoagulation therapy.
* Infection: The patient is at risk of developing further infections due to underlying immunocompromised status and antibiotic therapy.
* Neurological complications: The patient has a risk of further neurological complications due to underlying peripheral neuropathy and compression fracture.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Condition:**

* Respiratory failure with severe COPD on imaging, likely with superimposed infection
* Acute coronary syndrome with completed infarct and mid-LAD stenosis
* Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure with EF 20-25%
* Fevers, possibly related to infection or acute coronary syndrome
* Acute on chronic anemia, likely related to advanced HIV and medication effect
* Acute on chronic renal failure, stable with baseline creatinine 1.2
* Hypotension resolved, but still at risk
* Elevated AST, etiology unclear
* HIV/AIDS with CD4 count 28 and viral load 65
* Peripheral neuropathy and recent T8 compression fracture
* Hyperlipidemia, on hold for now

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pneumonia**: The patient's respiratory failure and bilateral consolidations on CT imaging suggest a high risk of pneumonia, particularly given their immunocompromised status.
2. **Cardiac Complications**: The patient's acute coronary syndrome and completed infarct increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac tamponade.
3. **Infection**: The patient's fevers, respiratory failure, and bilateral consolidations on CT imaging suggest a high risk of infection, which could be superimposed on their underlying COPD or related to their immunocompromised status.
4. **Renal Failure**: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure and potential nephrotoxicity from medications increase the risk of renal failure or worsening renal function.
5. **Hepatic Complications**: The patient's elevated AST and potential medication effect or infection-related liver damage increase the risk of hepatic complications, such as liver failure or encephalopathy.
6. **Neurological Complications**: The patient's peripheral neuropathy and recent T8 compression fracture increase the risk of neurological complications, such as paralysis, numbness, or weakness.
7. **Sepsis**: The patient's fevers, respiratory failure, and bilateral consolidations on CT imaging suggest a high risk of sepsis, particularly given their immunocompromised status.

**Assessment and Plan:**

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for 8 days, including vancomycin and zosyn, to cover potential infections.
2. Perform a mini-BAL to obtain bronchial cultures and gram stains, as well as to rule out Legionella, Pneumocystis, and CMV infections.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust therapy as needed to prevent respiratory failure.
4. Continue cardiology follow-up to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust therapy as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust medication dosing as needed to prevent worsening renal failure.
6. Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and adjust therapy as needed to prevent hepatic complications.
7. Perform a CT scan to further evaluate the patient's compression fracture and consider neurosurgical evaluation.
8. Continue HIV/AIDS treatment and prophylaxis, including HAART regimen, fluconazole, and Bactrim.

**Recommendations:**

1. Perform regular vital sign checks and monitor the patient's respiratory status closely.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust therapy as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust medication dosing as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and adjust therapy as needed.
5. Perform regular neurologic checks to monitor for potential complications.
6. Consider consulting with a pulmonologist, cardiologist, and infectious disease specialist to optimize the patient's care.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old man with a history of HIV, low CD4 count, presumed COPD, and CAD with a stent. He presented to the hospital with respiratory failure and ACS, and is currently in the ICU with completed infarct, new EF of 20%, and persistent respiratory failure.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure of 113/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 7 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 738 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 19 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and creatine kinase, as well as decreased albumin and calcium levels. His arterial blood gas results show a pH of 7.42, partial pressure of oxygen of 186 mmHg, and partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 59 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to his critical condition, but he is reportedly responding to verbal commands and has a normal sinus rhythm.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's persistent respiratory failure can lead to further decline in lung function, increased risk of pneumonia, and decreased oxygenation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's completed infarct and decreased ejection fraction can increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and sudden death.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate dehydrogenase levels suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and increased mortality.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's decreased platelet count and elevated international normalized ratio suggest the possibility of bleeding complications, particularly with invasive procedures.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's tube feeds and potential malnutrition can lead to deficiencies in essential nutrients, including protein, vitamins, and minerals.
6. Medication interactions: The patient's multiple medications, including antiretroviral therapy, can interact with each other and increase the risk of adverse effects, such as kidney damage and electrolyte imbalances.
7. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state and respiratory failure increase his risk of developing infections, particularly pneumonia and sepsis.
8. Organ dysfunction: The patient's critical condition can lead to organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, and gastrointestinal failure.

Given the patient's critical condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status, and to adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's current condition:

The patient is a 48-year-old man with a history of HIV, low CD4 count on HAART, presumed COPD, and CAD with a stent. He presented to the hospital with cough and dyspnea, and was transferred to the MICU with respiratory failure and acute coronary syndrome (ACS). He has completed an infarct, with a new ejection fraction of approximately 20%. He is currently on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a FiO2 of 50% and a PEEP of 14 cmH2O.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38°C, a heart rate of 89 bpm, a blood pressure of 113/71 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 7 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 94%, and his ABG results show a pH of 7.42, a PCO2 of 59 mmHg, and a PO2 of 186 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 4.2 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 10.9 g/dL, and a platelet count of 133 x 10^9/L. His liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an ALT level of 27 IU/L and an AST level of 73 IU/L. His renal function tests are normal, with a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 35 mg/dL.

The patient's plan includes continuing his mechanical ventilation, switching his IV steroids to oral prednisone 60 mg, and minimizing inspiratory pressures. He is also receiving regular insulin sliding scale for glycemic control, and has a multi-lumen central venous catheter, a 20-gauge peripheral IV line, and an arterial line in place.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to continued mechanical ventilation
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Pneumothorax or lung injury due to high airway pressures
* Sepsis or septic shock due to ongoing infection
* Cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to reduced ejection fraction
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or ulcers due to stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism due to prolonged immobility
* Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to insulin therapy
* Renal failure due to prolonged fluid overload or nephrotoxic medications

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old man with a history of HIV, low CD4 count, and presumed COPD and CAD, who presented to the emergency department with respiratory failure and acute coronary syndrome (ACS). He was transferred to the MICU with a completed infarct, new left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 20%, and persistent respiratory failure.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate of 89 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure of 113/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 7 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. His physical examination reveals a sedated and unresponsive patient with distant breath sounds, active exhalation with tight abdomen, and a diffuse erythematous rash.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 4.2, hemoglobin of 10.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 133 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated lactate level of 0.9 mmol/L.

The patient's respiratory support includes a ventilator with a tidal volume of 738 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 19 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. His arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.42, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 59 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 186 mmHg.

The patient's plan includes continuing his IV steroids and switching to oral prednisone 60 mg, as well as minimizing inspiratory pressures to reduce auto-peep. His IV antibiotics will be continued, and his code status is full code.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's persistent respiratory failure and requirement for mechanical ventilation put him at risk for further respiratory deterioration, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's new LVEF of 20% and history of ACS make him at risk for further cardiac complications, including cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
3. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of a central line, arterial line, and urinary catheter make him at risk for infection, including sepsis and catheter-related bloodstream infections.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and requirement for aspirin and clopidogrel therapy make him at risk for further gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and potential for further respiratory failure put him at risk for neurological complications, including seizures and brain injury.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical complications who requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration and improve his chances of survival.

   47 year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, [**Hospital 827**] transferred from OSH with
   respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome.
   # Respiratory failure: Severe COPD on imaging
 less wheezy on
   examination today.  Question superimposed infection
 CT shows
   bilateral consolidations, likely atelectasis, but will treat for
   infection given immunocompromised status.  Not much evidence of
   congestive heart failure contributing per CT from yesterday.
   - Change Solu-Medrol 125 mg IV Q8H to prednisone 60 mg PO daily
   - Continue combivent Q4H for COPD with albuterol Q1-2H PRN
   - Continue beclomethasone
   - Will continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn x 8
   days
   - Mini-BAL for: Bronchial culture & gram stain; Legionella culture;
   Rapid Respiratory Viral Screen & Culture; Pneumocystis smear; CMV
   culture; Acid fast (TB) culture & smear; Fungal culture
 all NGTD
   - Goal I/O even
   - Methadone 20 mg IV Q6H (higher than home equivalent of pain
   medication) for agitation on ventilator to decrease requirements of
   fentanyl/versed
   # Acute coronary syndrome: Completed infarct
 question mid-LAD
   stenosis.  Cardiac enzymes trending down.
   - Cardiology following; appreciate -> no intervention at this time,
   stress test when improved
   - Continue aspirin, plavix, metoprolol
 add on lisinopril today
   - Statin discontinued as outpatient due to interaction with HAART
   regimen
   # Acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure: TTE
   yesterday shows EF 20-25% from 30%.
   - Cardiology following; appreciate
   - Goal I/O even for now
   - Continue metoprolol
 add on lisinopril today
   - Cardiology follow-up as an outpatient for question AICD
   # Fevers: Fever to 102 prior to presentation
 afebrile since.  Due to
   infection versus acute coronary syndrome.  If infection, most likely
   etiology would be pulmonary.  CT shows bilateral consolidations, likely
   atelectasis, but will treat for infection given immunocompromised
   status.
   - Will continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn x 8
   days
   - Mini-BAL for: Bronchial culture & gram stain; Legionella culture;
   Rapid Respiratory Viral Screen & Culture; Pneumocystis smear; CMV

 all NGTD

 NGTD

 NGTD
   - Stool cultures
 NGTD
   # Acute on chronic anemia: Status post 3U PRBC.  BRBPR in setting of
   heparin gtt and integrillin gtt, none since.  No RP bleed on CT
   yesterday.  Chronic anemia likely related to his advanced HIV (marrow
   suppression and/or medication effect).
   - Guaiac stools
   - Recheck hematocrit in afternoon and transfuse < 28
   - Monitor
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Stable.  Baseline creatinine 1.2,
   recently 1.5 in [**Month (only) 1033**].
   - Goal even today
   - Renally dose medications
   - Monitor
   # Hypotension: Resolved.  Patient was on levophed on transfer but now
   off.
   - Monitor
   # Elevated AST: Etiology unclear; may be medication effect versus due
   to infection.  Other liver enzymes within normal limits.
   - Monitor
   # HIV/AIDS: CD4 count 28 with viral load 65.  Known to have virus with
   NNRTI resistance.
   - Continue home HAART regimen
   - Continue fluconazole for fungal prophylaxis
   - Continue Bactrim and [**Doctor First Name **] prophylaxis

 chronic on imaging here.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old man with advanced AIDS, CAD, and a history of respiratory failure, acute coronary syndrome, and chronic anemia. He was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department with severe COPD, acute coronary syndrome, and acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic congestive heart failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, FiO2 50%, and PEEP 14 cmH2O. His SpO2 is 95%, and his ABG results show pH 7.40, PaO2 216, and PaCO2 63.
* Cardiovascular: He has completed infarct with question mid-LAD stenosis, and his cardiac enzymes are trending down. He is receiving aspirin, plavix, metoprolol, and lisinopril.
* Infectious: He has bilateral consolidations on CT scan, likely atelectasis, but will be treated for infection given his immunocompromised status. He is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, zosyn, and mini-BAL for bronchial culture and gram stain.
* Gastrointestinal: He has a history of chronic anemia, and his current hemoglobin is 10.9 g/dL. He is receiving guaiac stools and will be rechecked for hematocrit in the afternoon.
* Renal: His baseline creatinine is 1.2, and his current creatinine is 1.5. He is receiving renally dosed medications and will be monitored.
* Liver: His AST is elevated, but the etiology is unclear. He will be monitored.
* HIV/AIDS: He has a CD4 count of 28 with viral load 65 and is receiving HAART regimen.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, respiratory acidosis, and hypoxemia.
* Cardiovascular: Myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, and arrhythmias.
* Infectious: Sepsis, pneumonia, and disseminated infection.
* Gastrointestinal: GI bleeding, pancreatitis, and liver failure.
* Renal: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalance.
* Liver: Hepatitis, liver failure, and jaundice.
* HIV/AIDS: Opportunistic infections, such as Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, and Kaposi's sarcoma.

The patient's current medications include:

* Solu-Medrol (changed to prednisone)
* Combivent
* Beclomethasone
* Vancomycin
* Zosyn
* Methadone
* Fentanyl
* Midazolam
* Aspirin
* Plavix
* Metoprolol
* Lisinopril
* Fluconazole
* Bactrim
* Acyclovir
* Piperacillin
